bioghist.p: Edward H. Dixon (1808-1880) was a prominent doctor in New York City in the mid-19th century. He was a surgeon and a thorn in the side of the establishment New York Academy of Medicine. According to the Academy he was "an able practitioner but utterly devoid of accepted ethical principles." Dixon published a journal, The Scalpel, to carry on his campaign against the Academy and to entertain and instruct the public about medical practices.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Edward H. Dixon include correspondence, certificates, and family papers. Materials of note include Dixon's medical license, 1880; a printed letter to members of the New York Academy of Medicine, 1879; letters to Dixon from the publisher of the Medical Journal of Boston and from A.A. Phillips, a defense lawyer; letters from Dixon to his granddaughters Julie and May and other women in the family; legal documents (wills and indentures) from the Brown, Hart, and Dixon families, 1801-1893; and Elias G. Brown's college diplomas (1846 and 1849) and the draft of a speech by Brown.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
